article.headline: Turiaf scores 29 for Bulldogs
article.linkText: Gonzaga storms away with BB&T Classic title
article.story: WASHINGTON -- Gonzaga made the type of East Coast impact it was hoping for, winning a tournament title despite some stormy resistance from a 3-point shooter from George Washington. The Bulldogs (No. 24 ESPN/USA Today, No. 17 AP) overcame a career-high 28 points from T.J. Thompson, who also shut down leading scorer Blake Stepp. It was left to the inside game, led by Ronny Turiaf's 29 points, to put away a 96-91 victory Sunday in the championship game of the BB&T Classic. "We weathered some serious storms and Nor'easters, so to speak, and hung in there," Gonzaga coach Mark Few said. "I just thought George Washington's effort and execution was phenomenal. We're lucky to get out of here with a win, the way they were shooting the basketball." Gonzaga shot 66 percent for the game, taking control early in the second half with a series of power moves and dunks that simply outmuscled the smaller Colonials. Turiaf led the way, matching his career high in points while making 9 of 14 field goals, 10 of 12 free throws and grabbing six rebounds. "We haven't faced anyone like that," Few said. "It took a while, but our guys adjusted." Backup guard Erroll Knight added 18 points for the Bulldogs (6-1), allowing Stepp to have a rare quiet game. Stepp couldn't shake Thompson's shadow and finished with just five points, his lowest output since last December. Gonzaga heads home from Washington, D.C., to Washington state having beaten two East Coast teams -- including Maryland on Saturday -- to help boost its national profile among poll voters and NCAA tournament seeders. "I'm really pleased," Few said. "We come back here, basically in these schools' neighborhoods and dig out two wins. It's huge." Thompson made 7 of 12 3-pointers for George Washington (5-2). He was on a tear in the first half, scoring 22 of his team's 52 points, but he was just 1-for-7 from the field in the second half. The Colonials' inside game was hurt by foul trouble that limited Pops Mensah-Bonsu to 12 minutes. Still, coach Karl Hobbs said the loss was his team's most complete game of the season. "This has been a learning experience," Hobbs said. "Hopefully, what we will get out of this is that we transfer playing 40 minutes hard for the rest of the season." The score was tied at 57 early in the second half when the Bulldogs started to take control with a 16-5 run that included two dunks from Sean Mallon and a three-point play from Cory Violette. An alley-oop to Turiaf got the lead to 14 with 8:20 to play. George Washington rallied to cut the lead to three on Carl Elliott's 3-pointer with less than 20 seconds remaining, but Kyle Bankhead made two free throws to keep the lead safe. West Virginia beat Maryland 78-77 in overtime in the third-place game.
